{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3229943,"name":null,"username":"pafen_ms","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/a5b964/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-09-07T02:45:40.941Z","cooked":"

I have been recently looking at visualizing the roboRIOs Smartdashboard data using networktables to capture the data by connecting to the robot. It uses a simple text based graphics library I’ve written for more control over the visuals but it uses the windows libraries for writing characters to the console window. The issue is that it seems that the WPILib extension only builds in linux athena so it will ignore the windows.h library and give an error.

My question is how can I build the project with the Windows.h libraries without disabling the wpilib package?

I’ve already tried changing the vscode configurations, properties and settings and playing around with the settings of all of the json files but it seems that it grabs the compiler settings from a different path entirely.

I don’t have enough c++ compiler and linker knowledge to know how to get these two to work together or if it’s even possible. The terminal just gives the “fatal error: Windows.h: No such file or directory #include <Windows.h>” error every time.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2023-09-07T02:45:40.941Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":107,"reads":89,"readers_count":88,"score":552.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":440595,"topic_slug":"unable-to-use-windows-libraries-with-wpilib-and-vs-code","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60331,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/unable-to-use-windows-libraries-with-wpilib-and-vs-code/440595/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3229965,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-07T04:07:29.095Z","cooked":"

The WPILib vscode extension and templates are designed for robot projects, not desktop applications. Since you’re using C++, you would probably be served best by using Visual Studio 2022 to create a new CMake project, then add the following to the CMakeLists.txt (where testDesktopApp is the name of your executable) to link to ntcore. Note this pulls from the head of the main branch (bleeding edge), you can also change the GIT_TAG to something like v2023.4.2 to use a stable tagged release.

include(FetchContent)

FetchContent_Declare(
  wpilib
  GIT_REPOSITORY https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib.git
  GIT_TAG        main
)
FetchContent_GetProperties(wpilib)
if(NOT wpilib_POPULATED)
  FetchContent_Populate(wpilib)
  set(WITH_JAVA off)
  set(WITH_CSCORE off)
  set(WITH_WPIMATH off)
  set(WITH_WPILIB off)
  set(WITH_TESTS off)
  set(WITH_GUI off)
  set(WITH_SIMULATION_MODULES off)
  set(BUILD_SHARED_LIBS off)
  add_subdirectory(${wpilib_SOURCE_DIR} ${wpilib_BINARY_DIR})
endif()

target_link_libraries(testDesktopApp PUBLIC ntcore)

Thanks for the help.
After changing a few of the CMake settings and setting it to build in c++17, it seems to be working fine. The network table is able to receive data from the Smartdashboard and the graphics library also works now.

But there was a slight issue with a file called PortForwarder.cpp which gave the error: [‘remotePtr’ cannot be implicitly captured because no default capture mode has been specified]. Since I don’t know how to specify a default capture mode, I just commented out the remotePtr->Close() line and everything seems to work fine. It might crash if the server closes the networktable connection first though.

pafen_ms:

But there was a slight issue with a file called PortForwarder.cpp which gave the error: [‘remotePtr’ cannot be implicitly captured because no default capture mode has been specified].

That’s odd. The above built fine for me when testing it locally. Are you using VS 2022? We also use C++20, not C++17.

NetworkTables doesn’t use PortForwarder so it won’t affect anything there.
